text.tspan: There are many complaints about the education system in India being inclined towards
rote memorization and requiring long stretches of regular study hours in order to achieve
academic success (Bhargava & Tiwari, 2019). This reduces the time for entertainment,
recreational activities, and socialism, an essential part of a child's development. Teachers often
assign excessive homework, resort to shouting and beating as punishments, and restrict extra-
curricular and recreational activities in an attempt to improve students' focus on their academic
performance (Parikh et al., 2019). However, these methods are proven to be counterproductive,
establishing a vicious cycle of guilt, low self-confidence, lack of productivity, and poor
performance in students, which further results in negative stress affecting their mental health
(Parikh et al., 2019). Homework is the most negative aspect of schoolwork among students due
to its significant association with frequent episodes of anger, irritability, stress, and boredom
(Verma et al., 2002). Although disciplinary measures in schools vary from institution to
institution, corporal punishment is practiced in most of the schools in India (Deb et al., 2015).
The majority of students also exhibit anxieties related to examinations (Deb et al., 2015).
Stress levels among high school students are significantly higher during the "board classes," i.e.,
10th and 12th-grade, as compared to 9th and 11th-grade (Bhasin et al., 2010). Female students
experience more examination-related anxiety than their male counterparts (Deb et al., 2015). In
2011 alone, 2,381 children – more than six children per day – committed suicide because of
failure in examinations (National Crime Records Bureau [NCRB], 2011). These statistics rose to
an alarming 130,000 student suicides in 2018 (approximately 28 students per day) (NCRB,
2018). Although the reasons are innumerable, failure in examinations, unemployment, and
